head.title: Chechen Rebels Kill 37 Russian Soldiers In Truck Bombings

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/World/Countries and Territories/Russia and the Former Soviet Union

hedline.hl1: Chechen Rebels Kill 37 Russian Soldiers In Truck Bombings

abstract.p: Chechen suicide bombers set off series of blasts throughout breakaway republic, killing at least 37 Russian soldiers and wounding 74; five trucks laden with explosives blow up in towns and cities ostensibly under Russian control; carefully coordinated rebel attack occurs just a week after Russian military declared that war is all but won; as toll of dead and wounded mounts, Moscow vows to break back of rebel resistance; rebels respond by saying they plan still more bombings; rumors are rife that Grozny, Chechen capital, will be attacked next; photo; map (M)

block.p: Chechen suicide bombers have set off a series of devastating blasts throughout the breakaway Russian republic, killing at least 37 Russian soldiers and wounding 74, officials said today.
In a carefully coordinated rebel attack late Sunday night, five trucks laden with explosives blew up in towns and cities that were ostensibly under Russian control.
Chechen suicide bombers have set off a series of devastating blasts throughout the breakaway Russian republic, killing at least 37 Russian soldiers and wounding 74, officials said today.
In a carefully coordinated rebel attack late Sunday night, five trucks laden with explosives blew up in towns and cities that were ostensibly under Russian control.
The bombings caught the Russian military unprepared and took place just a week after the military had declared that the war was all but won.

As the toll of dead and wounded continued to climb -- one unofficial count put it at 44 soldiers killed and 120 wounded -- Moscow vowed to break the back of the rebel resistance. ''There is only one thing that can be done -- to find and crush them,'' said Col. Gen. Valery Manilov, the deputy chief of staff of the Russian forces, who called off a trip to Britain because of the attacks. ''Talks will not help. You can see what is happening there.''
But the rebels said they were planning still more bombings, and Grozny, the Chechen capital, was rife with rumors that it was about to be attacked.

Chechen fighters won de facto control of the region in a war with Russia in 1994-96. Russian forces returned last year after militants based in Chechnya attacked villages in the neighboring region of Dagestan.

The use of suicide bombings represents a new stage of the war. In the nine months of fighting, Russian forces have swept through the northern plains, seized Grozny, taken the major cities and towns in the Chechen lowlands and pursued the Chechen rebels in the southern mountains.

What they have not been able to do is pacify the restive population and weed out the enemies in their midst. Unable to take on the heavily equipped Russian military on its own terms, the militants are mounting a guerrilla war. Rebels have infiltrated the major towns, drawing support from local Chechens who are embittered by the indiscriminate Russian attacks. Col. Gen. Gennadi Troshev, the commander of Russian forces in Chechnya, insisted that he had recently instructed his troops to be especially vigilant, particularly in inspecting trucks.

But trucks full of explosives operated by suicide drivers still managed to elude Russian checkpoints on Sunday and approach several major towns, possibly leaving from a base near Serzhen-Yurt, a settlement the Russians said they had seized last week in a fierce battle.

The evidence of Russian laxity was painfully evident today. In Argun, a town east of Grozny that has been fought over several times during the year, a truck filled with explosives smashed into a dormitory housing militia from the region of Chelyabinsk in Russia's Ural Mountains. The militia's tour of duty had just ended and they were set to go home. Instead, at least 30 died in the blast, which created a huge crater, 5 yards deep and 10 yards wide.

Russian officials conceded the dormitory had been poorly protected. ''The dormitory building was not well enough defended from the outside,'' said Sergei Yastrzhembsky, a Russian government spokesman. ''As far as I know, the entrance to the territory was blocked only by a Kamaz truck. There were no concrete barricades.''
In Gudermes, which functions as the administrative capital of the region, the Russian military was more successful. Two trucks full of explosives were stopped at the outskirts of the city.

The drivers were killed and a Russian as well as Chechen soldiers died when the trucks exploded. One of the drivers was believed to be trying to kill Akhmad Kadyrov, the Chechen official picked by President Vladimir V. Putin to govern Chechnya, according to Russian officials.
Another truck full of explosives, also believed headed for Gudermes, was stopped near the settlement of Novogroznensky. It rammed into an Interior Ministry unit, killing three and wounding 20.
Yet another truck exploded near the office of the military commandant in Urus-Martan. Itblew up as it tried to ram the building, killing two soldiers in a concrete shelter.
The Russians later announced that they had detained 18 people suspected of involvement in the blast.

More than 2,100 Russian soldiers have been killed and 6,000 wounded since Oct. 1. The nation is weary of the war, but not to the point where the Russian public is willing to cede control of Chechnya to the rebels.
With each bombing or ambush, the Russians seem to have become more bitter. And with each airstrike or artillery barrage, the Chechens seem to have become angrier at their Russian masters.

On the Russian side, the Chelyabinsk region is an example. It had promised to help restore the town of Argun, one of the targets of the bombings on Sunday. But stung by the loss of fighters, the Chelyabinsk governor said the region would no longer help, ensuring the restoration of Chechnya would take longer.
''As long as they kill our guys I won't give them a ruble,'' said Gov. Pyotr Sumin. ''And nobody will make me do this.''
For the Chechens, much of the enmity is directed not only at the Russians but also at Chechens who are cooperating with the Russians.
Aslan Maskhadov, the separatist president of Chechnya before the Russian intervention, essentially called for the death of Mr. Kadyrov, the Russian-appointed leader of Chechnya.
In an address that is recorded on videocassette and available in Chechnya, Mr. Maskhadov called Mr. Kadyrov ''the main enemy of the Chechen people.''

''The people will appreciate the services of the one who manages to remove him more than all the heroic deeds performed by Chechen fighters in all wars in the course of the last 400 years,'' Mr. Maskhadov said.
